sen.j: 院宮王臣家（いんぐうおうしんけ）とは、平安時代初期(8世紀末～9世紀ごろ)、天皇権力と結びついて勢力を強めた少数の皇族・貴族の総称。
sen.e: Engu oshinke is a collective term that refers to the limited number of imperial families and nobles who gathered strength in the beginning of Heian Period by taking advantage of their relationship with the Emperor.

Engu oshinke is a term from the early Heian period. It is a collective term referring to a limited number of imperial families and nobles who gathered strength by taking advantage of their relationship with the Emperor.
sen.cmt: turned this sentence into two since it was uncomfortably long as only one
sen.e: Engu oshinke is a collective term referring to a limited number of imperial families and nobles who gathered strength by taking advantage of their relationship with the Emperor in the early Heian Period (8th to 9th century).
sen.cmt: 「平安時代初期(8世紀末～9世紀ごろ)」を補足し、一文に。

sen.j: 「院宮王臣家」の「院」とは太上天皇、「宮」とは三宮(皇后・皇太后・太皇太后)・東宮(皇太子)を指す。
sen.e: Engu oshinke is written in Chinese character as "院宮王臣家", and "院" refers to Daijo Tenno (the retired Emperor), "宮" refers to Sangu (Empress, Empress Dowager and Great Empress Dowager) and Togu (the Crown Prince) and "王臣家" refers to Emperor's family like Imperial prince/Imperial princess and court nobles whose court rank was Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) or higher respectively.

Engu oshinke is written in Chinese characters as "院宮王臣家." The character "院" refers to the Daijo Tenno (retired Emperor), the character "宮" refers to the Sangu (Empress, Empress Dowager and Great Empress Dowager) and the Togu (Crown Prince). The characters "王臣家" refer to the Emperor's family, such as the Imperial Prince, Imperial Princess and court nobles with a court rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) or higher.
sen.cmt: split this sentence into three sentences to make it easier to read; fixed grammar where needed
sen.e: Engu oshinke is written in Chinese characters as "院宮王臣家" and the character "院" refers to the Daijo Tenno (retired Emperor), the character "宮" refers to the Sangu (Empress, Empress Dowager and Great Empress Dowager) and the Togu (Crown Prince).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: また、「王臣家」とは親王・内親王などの皇親や、おおむね従五位以上の貴族をそれぞれ指している。
sen.e: The characters "王臣家" refer to the Emperor's family, such as the Imperial Prince, Imperial Princess and court nobles with a court rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) or higher.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 平安時代になると公地公民制は事実上崩壊していた。
sen.e: As kouchikominsei (System of complete state ownership of land and citizens) was effectively dysfunctional in the Heian Period, chokueiden (rice fields that were directly managed) such as Kueiden (lands directly managed by the government to secure revenues) and Kanden (imperial estates) as well as privately-owned land such as Shoshiden (tax-exempt lands that were provided to cover the labor cost of shoshi (officials)), Chokushiden (lands developed by Imperial order) and Shiden (lands given by Emperor) were increasing.

During the Heian period there was the kouchikominsei (a system of complete state ownership of land and citizens) which was effectively dysfuntional. As a result of this system there was a sharp increase in chokueiden (rice fields managed directly), such as Kueiden (land managed directly by the government to secure revenue) and Kanden (imperial estates), as well as privately-owned land, such as Shoshiden (land exempt from taxes provided to cover labor costs of shoshi (officials), Chokushiden (land developed by Imperial order) and Shiden (land donated by the Emperor).
sen.cmt: split this sentence into two sentences to make it easier to read; fixed grammar
sen.e: During the Heian period there was the kouchikominsei (a system of complete state ownership of land and citizens) which was effectively dysfunctional.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処、dysfuntionaｌ→dysfunctional

sen.j: また、公営田や官田などの直営田や、諸司田・勅旨田・賜田などの私有地が増大していた。
sen.e: As a result of this system there was a sharp increase in chokueiden (rice fields managed directly), such as Kueiden (land managed directly by the government to secure revenue) and Kanden (imperial estates), as well as privately-owned land, such as Shoshiden (land exempt from taxes provided to cover labor costs of shoshi (officials), Chokushiden (land developed by Imperial order) and Shiden (land donated by the Emperor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 院宮王臣家は下級官人を家人化し，有力農民を保護することで、これらの私有地の集積を進めていった。
sen.e: Under such situation, Enguoshinke accumulated these privately-owned lands by making lower-ranking government officials their own subordinates and protecting influential peasants.
Under these circumstances, the Engu oshinke accumulated these privately-owned lands by protecting influential peasants and turning lower-ranking government officials into their own subordinates.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence to read more naturally
sen.e: Under these circumstances, the Engu oshinke accumulated these privately-owned lands by protecting influential peasants and turning lower-ranking government officials into their own subordinates.

sen.j: この動きは、初期荘園から寄進地系荘園(内部リンク「荘園」を参照)への移行を如実に表すものである。
sen.e: This movement clearly demonstrates the shift from shoki shoen (early stage shoen) to kishinchikei shoen (shoen whose origin was the lands donated by developers for the purpose of tax-exemption etc.) (refer to internal link "Shoen").
sen.cmt: 寄進地系荘園 -定訳不明
sen.e: This movement clearly demonstrates the shift from early stage shoen to kishinchikei shoen (shoen that were originally donated by developers for the purpose of tax-exemption etc.) (refer to internal link "Shoen").
sen.cmt: eliminated description in parenthesis (early stage shoen) and moved it into the sentence; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: This movement clearly demonstrates the shift from early stage shoen to kishinchikei shoen (shoen that were originally donated by developers for the purpose of tax-exemption etc.) (refer to internal link "Shoen").

sen.j: なお、類した表現として「権門勢家」があるが、これは院宮王臣家だけでなく、宗教勢力や武家勢力をも含む上位概念である。
sen.e: In the meantime, the term "Kemnon seika" (great and powerful families), a similar term to Engu oshinke, is a broader concept that collectively refers to Engu oshinke, powerful religious institutions and samurai families.

In addition to the term "Engu oshinke," there is the term "Kenmon seika," which is similar in meaning but carries a broader concept, referring collectively to Engu oshinke, powerful religious institutions and samurai families.
sen.cmt: Kemnon→Kenmon; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In addition to the term "Engu oshinke," there is the term "Kenmon seika," which is similar in meaning but carries a broader concept, referring collectively to Engu oshinke, powerful religious institutions and samurai families.
